div1.p:
135. (M.)
William Cayley
was indicted for
stealing a heifer, value 5 l. the property of
William Watkins
, Dec. 11
. ++

William Watkins
. I am a gardener , and live at Hounslow
; I lost a heifer from off the heath on the 9th or 10th of December, she not coming home with her company as usual; I had intelligence of her on the Friday se'nnight after; I went as directed, and found her at Weybridge in Surrey, in the possession of
Thomas Keen
; I described her to him before I saw her, a short, little, low, brindle heifer, with the tip of her horns on; I had bought her about six weeks before Michaelmas, at Barnet-fair for 4 l. 10 s. she is now high calving.
Q. Did you know the prisoner before?
Watkins. I did, he has been at my house for radishes for his wife to sell; he lived at Hounslow.

Thomas Keen
. I live at Weybridge, on the 11th of December the prisoner was driving this heifer through the village, between eight and nine in the morning, that was Cobham fair day, about four miles from my house; I asked him where he was going with her; he said to Cobham fair; I said, where did you bring her from; he said from Ashford in Middlesex, and that she was his own, that he bought her of old Benham of Heffon; I said what is the price; he said four guineas and a half; I turned and was going in at my door, he hallooed after me, and said if I had a mind to have her, I should have her worth my money, as he was obliged to make up his rent against Christmas; I said you must bate a good deal; I thought she might be worth about 50 s. then he asked three guineas, but at last took my 50 s. I turned her into the yard, and paid the money, and took a receipt; I asked a neighbour the value of her, who told me she was worth double the money I had given; then I said to know the truth, I would go to Cobham fair, and hear what they asked for such a thing; I went and found as my neighbour had said; when I went about the fair to see if I could find the man I bought her of, in searching I found him; I told him the heifer I bought of him was worth double the money, I feared he did not come honestly by her; he swore she was his own; I said I shall not let you go, till you give me an account how you came by her; he had sold me the heifer in the name of
William Ballanger
; I saw a man that came from about a mile from Ashford, that man said he knew the prisoner, and that his name was
William Cayley
; while I was talking to another person, the prisoner slipt away; on the Monday following I went to Ashford, and enquired if any body had lost an heifer, and a person informed me the prosecutor, who lived at Hounslow had; the prisoner was taken after that, and I delivered the heifer to the prosecutor.
Q. How came you to think the heifer was worth no more than 50 s.?
Keen. My father was a butcher, and when I was a lad, I remember that was about the price for such then; I do not trade in that way, and was an utter stranger to the value of her.
The prisoner said nothing in his defence.

(M.) He was a second time indicted for
stealing a black mare, value 30 s. the property of
John Stacey
, Dec. 7
. ++

Edward Shepcut
. I live at Hounslow, the prisoner was taken up for stealing the cow, and after he was committed he confessed he stole three horses of mine; he gave me an account of a key that opened a door at Lord Portmore's, that he used to take out of a hole, and open the door to put the horses into a stable, till the man came in the morning, and he used to have 5 s. a piece for them; I went there and opened the door, and looked in, there was the whiper in. I said here is nothing of mine, but here is Mr. Stacey's mare, a neighbour of mine, I knew her well; then I sent to Mr. Stacey; she was then sent to Weybridge, he went the next morning and brought her home; when we brought the prisoner before Sir
John Fielding
, he there confessed he sold her for a guinea to the huntsman; this was when he was ordered up from Newgate last Thursday; the huntsman had docked her.

John Stacey
. The mare belongs to me; after I missed her I went a great way about after her, but Mr. Shepcut happened to see her in that stable, by which means I got her again; I was before Sir
John Fielding
when the prisoner was ordered up from Newgate, there he owned he had taken my mare, and sold her to my Lord's huntsman.
Q. Where did you lose your mare from?

Stacey. I lost her from out of a field, about half a mile from Hounslow
; the huntsman told me he bought my mare of the prisoner.
Q. to Shepcut. Does the huntsman farm the feeding the hounds?
Shepcut. I have heard he does; I have lost three horses, they are all killed.
